Best Same-Day Loans

Not all same-day loans are the same in terms of convenience and affordability. Compare your options closely before you apply.

By Meredith Mangan

    Same-day loans can take many forms, including a credit card cash advance, a cash app advance, a BNPL purchase, or a personal loan. Of these, personal loans are the best same-day loans because loan amounts are higher, interest rates are generally much lower, and you have longer to pay the loan back (meaning smaller monthly payments). Our picks for the best same-day personal loans are LightStream, SoFi, and Rocket Loans.

    Overview

    LightStream is one of three Credible partner lenders to offer loan amounts up to $100,000, which makes it ideal for financing large expenses. Plus, average rates on LightStream personal loans were the lowest among all Credible partner lenders for borrowers with good, very good, and excellent credit, according to 12 months of Credible personal loans marketplace data. There are no origination fees or other fees, and loans can be used for a wide range of purposes

     

    Funds can be available as soon as the same day you apply, and you could have up to 20 years to repay certain types of loans, including home improvement loans, RV loans, and boat loans. 

     

    Unlike most lenders, LightStream does not let you prequalify on its site — but you can prequalify through Credible. LightStream scored better than average in J.D. Power's 2025 U.S. Consumer Lending Satisfaction Study, beating out online lender SoFi by one position.

    pros

    • Ultra-low interest rates
    • No fees
    • $100,000 loans available
    • Allows co-borrowers
    • Same-day funding possible
    • Repayment terms up to 20 years
    • 6th in consumer lending satisfaction

    cons

    • No loans under $5,000
    • Requires good to excellent credit
    • No changing monthly due dates
    • Limited customer service
    • Can't prequalify on the lender's site

    Overview

    Rocket Loans delivers no-frills same-day personal loans with a generous autopay discount to good-credit borrowers and some borrowers with fair credit. APRs and available loan amounts are competitive — Rocket Loans offers loans up to $45,000. Plus, the company offers small business loans if you apply directly through its website. Notably, Rocket Loans delivered lower average rates than many competitors to borrowers with very good and excellent credit (based on closed loans data from the Credible marketplace over the last 12 months).

     

    However, you'll only have a choice between two repayment terms — 3 or 5 years — and origination fees can be as high as 9.99%. You may qualify with fair credit, but Rocket Loans doesn't offer cosigned or secured options that could help you qualify or lower your rate.

    pros

    • Funding as soon as the same day

    • Low rates for very good and excellent credit

    cons

    • Origination fee up to 9.99% of the loan amount
    • No cosigned or secured loans
    • Only two repayment term options: 36 or 60 months

    Overview

    SoFi personal loans feature high loan amounts, competitive interest rates, as soon as same-day funding, and long loan terms, plus discounts for autopay and direct pay. Plus, SoFi offers live chat and free financial advice for customers. Unlike many other online lenders, SoFi is an FDIC-insured bank, which means SoFi makes loans directly and does not partner with a third-party to originate loans. It also means that you could have your checking, savings, and loan accounts all in one place. 

     

    To qualify for an unsecured loan, it's best to have good credit. But unlike other lenders, SoFi doesn't specify a credit score minimum. It also has optional origination fees — you might elect to pay one to reduce your interest rate. Minimum loan amounts start at $5,000.

    pros

    • Large loan amounts available
    • Autopay and direct pay discounts
    • Same day funding
    • Long loan terms available

    cons

    • Not transparent about minimum credit score requirements
    • 5,000 minimum loan amount

    Cutoff times for same-day lending

    Funding cutoff times for same-day loans
    LightStream
    2:30 p.m. EST
    Rocket Loans
    4:00 p.m. EST
    SoFi
    6:00 p.m. EST

    *All cutoff times are approximate for each lender.

    Important

    If you live in a different time zone from the same-day lender you’re considering, make sure you account for the time difference. For example, 4 p.m. Central time is 5 p.m. Eastern time — one hour past the same-day cutoff time for Rocket Loans.

    How do same-day loans work?

    Same-day loans can be approved and funded on the same day you apply. In other words, you could apply for a loan in the morning, be approved in the afternoon, and receive the money before evening. Some same-day loans, like cash advances via an app, your credit card, and payday loans, are nearly instant. But they typically have much higher rates than personal loans and shorter payback periods — which could lead to a cycle of repeat borrowing. 

    Types of same-day loans

    Depending on the type of same-day loan you get, your overall cost can vary greatly. As well as the amount you can borrow and the amount of time you have to pay it back. Generally speaking, the lower the APR, the lower the cost. 

    Average APRs
    Repayment terms
    Typical loan amounts
    Personal loans
    11.14%, 2-year personal loan
    2 - 7 years (longer for some loan purposes)
    Up to $50,000
    Credit card cash advance
    30%, plus fees
    No set term
    20% to 30% of your available credit limit
    Cash advance app
    367% (if fees)
    2 weeks, typically
    Up to $500
    Payday loans
    200% to over 400%
    2 weeks, typically
    Up to $500
    BNPL
    0% to 36%
    6 weeks (0% interest) to 4 years
    A few hundred to thousands of dollars

    Average personal loan interest rates are from the Federal Reserve's Consumer Credit report.

    • Personal loans: Personal loans have a fixed interest rate, typically between 6.49% and 35.99%, and payments are made in equal monthly installments. Loan amounts generally range from $1,000 to $50,000, depending on the lender and your qualifications. Repayment terms typically last up to 7 years. A few lenders offer personal loans as soon as the same day, including LightStream, SoFi, and Rocket Loans.
    • Credit card cash advances: A credit card cash advance can be quick and convenient — just take your card to an ATM or bank office and borrow against your credit limit. However, various fees and APRs typically higher than the standard purchase rate can make it an expensive type of borrowing. The amount you can borrow is typically a percentage of your credit limit, such as 20% or 30%.
    • Payday loans: Payday loans are typically two-week loans for less than $500. Repayment is deducted from your bank account when your next paycheck is deposited. Payday loans have been widely criticized by lawmakers and consumer advocates because of exploitative costs and lending practices — APRs commonly range up to and over 400%, depending on your state. Even if you have bad credit or no credit, there are better options. 
    • Cash-advance apps: Cash-advance apps such as Chime MyPay, EarnIn Cash Out, and Empower use your banking history to determine how much you can borrow, which are potentially less costly versions of payday loans. Funds can be available within minutes, but that will cost you. Cash apps are generally not recommended if you need to pay for instant delivery or have an ongoing need for cash.
    • Buy now, pay later apps: BNPL apps such as Affirm, Afterpay, and Klarna commonly let you split a purchase into four equal payments, with an initial down payment, then due every two weeks with no interest. Longer terms are also available, but often carry interest charges similar to personal loans. 
    • Pawnshop loans: You might borrow money from a local pawnshop based on the value of an item you own, such as a wedding ring or laptop. What you think your item may be worth, however, is likely much more than what the pawnshop will, and you’ll only be able to borrow a portion of its assessed value. If you don’t repay the loan, you’ll lose your item.

    What can I use a same-day loan for?

    Most same-day loans provide cash — often direct-deposited into your bank account or as cash in hand — that you can use for whatever you need. Whether that's paying a vet bill, paying rent, buying groceries, or getting a needed car repair, a same-day loan can help you cover a range of unexpected or emergency expenses.

    There can be some restrictions on what you can use the funds for, however, depending on the type of loan. For instance, when you apply for a personal loan, you need to tell the lender how you intend to use it, and may be obligated to use the funds for that purpose only. You also aren't generally allowed to borrow money for illegal activities. 

    If you're concerned about restrictions, talk to the lender before applying.

    How to compare loans

    Given that there are different types of same-day loans and different purposes for getting one, there are a few factors to consider when deciding between them.

    Factor
    Description
    Example/Detail
    Minimum borrower requirements
    Minimum credit score, income, and debt-to-income (DTI) requirements
    Know whether the lender will check your credit and whether you can meet its minimum requirements.
    Fees
    Origination fees, expedited funds fees, and late fees
    Origination fees and expedited funds fees are commonly charged upfront and increase the APR.
    APR (annual percentage rate)
    Expresses the cost to borrow on an annual basis
    Accounts for the interest rate (if one) and upfront fees. The lower the APR, the less expensive the loan.
    Loan amount
    The amount the lender typically offers borrowers
    Some same-day loans cap loan amounts below $1,000, while others (like personal loans) may offer up to $50,000 or more.
    Repayment terms
    The duration you have to pay off the loan
    A longer repayment term can give you a smaller monthly payment and a potentially larger loan amount.
    Funding time
    How long until you get the money
    If you can wait a few hours or a day for money, try a personal loan first. If you need it instantly, consider BNPL or a cash app.
    Financial goal
    What you want to accomplish with the loan
    Determine whether the loan is addressing a short-term need or a long-term one. If you’re confident you can repay the money within weeks, consider a credit card cash advance or possibly a cash app. If you need more time, go with a personal loan.

    The most important feature to compare between same-day loans — aside from how quickly the lender can make the funds available — is APR. The APR, or annual percentage rate, is a measure of how much the loan costs on an annual basis, accounting for both the interest rate and any upfront lender fees. This is important because some zero-interest or no-interest loans charge steep fees relative to the amount borrowed and the timeline for repayment, which can make them much more expensive and difficult to repay than an interest-charging personal loan.

    For example, you might borrow $250 via a cash app and have the money deposited into your account instantly. But since most cash apps charge instant transfer fees or fees to expedite delivery, you’d need to account for that in the total cost of the loan. A regular personal loan calculator won’t get you there, but you can use a payday loan calculator or another calculator for short-term loans to figure out the APR. 

    • Amount borrowed: $250
    • Instant transfer fee: $5.99
    • Payment due in two weeks
    • APR: 62.5%
    • APR with $5 tip: 114.6%

    The 62.5% APR associated with the cash advance above makes this an expensive way to borrow — it’s even more expensive if you add a tip. (The instant transfer fee is based on EarnIn's fees for expedited delivery.)

    Editor insight: "To get a same-day personal loan, ensure there are no errors on your application, respond promptly to lender requests, and apply early enough in the day to complete all loan requirements before the lender's funding cutoff time."

    — Meredith Mangan, Senior Loans Editor, Credible

    Pros and cons

    The pros and cons of same-day loans depend on the type of same-day loan you get. We break it down below:

    Personal loans

    Pros

    • Fast funding
    • Reports to the credit bureaus (can build credit)
    • Lump sum payment
    • Large loan amounts
    • Years-long repayment terms
    • Low, fixed interest rates
    • Relatively low fees

    Cons

    • Credit check required
    • Could take hours for approval and funding
    • Might not qualify with bad credit
    • Origination fees can reduce the amount you receive

    Short-term loans (cash apps, payday loans, pawnshop loans)

    These loans include payday loans and cash advance apps, as well as some pawnshop loans.

    Pros

    • Almost-instant delivery of funds
    • No credit check required
    • Short, fast application process

    Cons

    • Potentially very high interest rates/fees
    • Short repayment terms
    • Typically don't build credit
    • Could lose collateral (pawnshop loans)
    • Small loan amounts

    How to apply for a same-day personal loan

    If you've never borrowed money or you've only used other forms of short-term borrowing, it might feel uncomfortable applying for a same-day personal loan. Getting familiar with the application process before you go through it may help. Here's what you'll need to do:

    1. Prequalify: Through a simple online prequalification process, you can find out which lenders are more likely to approve your application. Just enter some basic personal information, and you'll get an estimate of the APR, loan amount, and repayment terms you might qualify for. (Click any “Check Rates” button in this article to see which Credible partners might approve you.) Prequalification doesn’t affect your credit score, but a personal loan application that involves a hard credit inquiry — which is typical — could lower your score by up to 10 points for up to a year.
    2. Pick a loan: From the loans you prequalified with, choose the option that works best for you. That might be the least expensive loan, the one that can provide money the soonest, or the one with the lowest monthly payments. Note the lender’s same-day funding cutoff time.
    3. Complete the application early: You’ll complete your application directly on the lender's website. Do this as early as is feasible so you can get money today. Lenders may ask for your state-issued identification, recent pay stubs, and/or recent bank statements.
    4. Review and sign the loan agreement: Once you're approved, take your time to review the loan agreement. Make sure you understand the loan requirements and that you're OK with the APR, loan term, monthly payment, and, especially, upfront fees. Even though you're in a hurry to get money, don't rush this step.
    5. Get your money: After returning your signed documents to the lender, it should tell you when to expect the funds in your account.

    Learn More: How To Apply for a Personal Loan

    Important

    A prequalified rate quote doesn’t represent an offer of credit — it’s just an estimate of rates and terms you might qualify for if you apply. The rates and terms of loan offers you receive after you apply might be different.

    Alternatives

    • Payday alternative loans (PALs): Payday alternative loans, offered by some federal credit unions, are similar to personal loans but APRs top out at 28%. You may be able to borrow up to $2,000 at a fixed rate and repay it over 12 months. However, you’ll need to be a member of a credit union offering them to qualify or be eligible for membership. 
    • Family and friends: It might be better to set up a loan arrangement with a family member. You could potentially benefit from a much lower rate, and they could benefit from earning interest on the amount you borrow. But if mishandled, such an arrangement can ruin relationships. Put everything in writing and get professional advice if borrowing more than $10,000. 
    • Government and local resources: If your need is ongoing rather than a one-time expense or you don’t know if you can repay the loan, try to reduce your cost of living via government and local resources. Check 211.org for help with housing, food, utilities, disaster recovery, and more. 

    Learn More: 9 Personal Loan Alternatives

    • Cash advance apps (367% APR on average for advances repaid in 7-14 days)
    • Credit card cash advances (around 30% variable APR)

    Methodology

    Credible evaluated 32 lenders across 1,216 data points to find best same-day loans. All lenders selected can fund approved loans as soon as the same day you apply, provided you apply by that lender's cutoff time for same-day funding. We chose the best lenders based on the following weighted categories:

    • Rates and fees: 18.75%
    • Eligibility and options for bad and no credit: 17.5%
    • Availability: 12.5%
    • Loan amounts and terms: 10%
    • Customer satisfaction: 10%
    • Customer service: 10%
    • Efficiency and fund delivery: 10%
    • Discounts: 7.5%
    • Credible proprietary data: 3.75%

    Credible's team of experts gathered information from each lender’s website and from our partners directly. We also considered each of our partner lenders’ statistics over a 12-month period — including average funding times, average credit scores for approved applicants, and average rates. Each data point is verified by a senior editor to make sure it’s accurate at the time of publication.

    FAQ

    Are same-day loans and payday loans the same?

    Open

    Whether a same-day loan is better than using a credit card depends on your specific needs and goals. Credit card cash advances provide quick access to funds but often have high fees and interest rates. Same-day personal loans might offer lower rates and longer repayment terms, which could be better for larger borrowing needs. BNPL can be a good option for specific purchases if you can afford an upfront down payment and repay within the interest-free period. 

     

    Compare the APR, fees, and repayment expectations with each option to see which works best for you.

    Read more: Payday Loans vs. Personal Loans

    Where can I get a same-day loan?

    Open

    You can get same-day loans from online lenders like LightStream, Rocket Loans, and SoFi. Payday loans are available from storefront lenders and online (though these loans are not advised). Cash advance apps are available through Dave, EarnIn, MoneyLion, and many others. Credit unions may offer same-day payday alternative loans (PALs). BNPL apps can be found by visiting the sites of providers like Affirm, Klarna, and Sezzle, or via many retailer websites.

    Read more: Where Can I Get a Personal Loan?

    Are same-day loans better than using a credit card?

    Open

    Same-day loans and credit cards are both tools that you can use to cover immediate expenses. Credit cards are a type of revolving debt where you pay as you go, while a same-day loan has a closed term with a beginning and an end. 

     

    Credit cards are generally better for small, everyday expenses. Using a personal loan for a large, one-time purchase could give you more time to repay the money you've borrowed, and the APR might be lower.

    Read more: Personal Loan vs. Credit Card

    Can you get a same-day loan without a credit check?

    Open

    Yes, some same-day loans, such as payday and pawnshop loans, don’t require a credit check. Cash advance apps often don't perform traditional credit checks, but will access and assess your banking information. However, loans that don’t check your credit often have much higher rates than loans that do. Most personal loan lenders will check your credit as part of the application process, but you might still get a personal loan even with bad credit. Plus, the rate would likely be much lower than no-credit-check alternatives.

    Read more: No-Credit-Check Loans: Where To Get One and Alternatives

    Can you get a same-day loan for bad credit?

    Open

    Yes, you may be able to get a same-day loan with bad credit, but your options will be limited and the terms less favorable. Some lenders offer personal loans to borrowers with bad credit — start by prequalifying with bad-credit lenders. Though these loans typically have higher APRs than other personal loans, they’ll be much lower than payday loans and most cash apps. Plus, you can typically borrow a larger amount.  If you apply with a cosigner, get a joint personal loan, or get a secured loan, you might have a better chance of qualifying.

    Read more: Pros and Cons of Bad Credit Personal Loans

    Disclosure: Some lending partners that participate in Credible’s comparison marketplace offer loans to borrowers with scores as low as 550. Borrowers with low scores will have fewer lending options than borrowers with higher credit scores.
